meeting_annotations.speaker: Kathryn Haas
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, I'm Catherine Haas. I'm a chemist at Duke University and my group studies metal protein interactions. So mainly I use spectroscopies to characterize metal binding sites. And I'm really interested in metal homeostasis, particularly copper homeostasis and one of the proteins I study is a copper transporter, a transmembrane transporter. So one of the things that's always bugged me about the paradigm for how copper is transported through the cell is there's not really any explanation for how the how metal ions get to the transporter or or are carried away exactly. It doesn't seem to make sense that diffusion is the process involved here. So I I would like to better understand how the membrane itself can be kind of a scaffold for organizing proteins both inside and outside the cell so that pathways work quickly enough for for biology to happen.

I'm also interested in using biosensors to regulate metabolic behaviors of cells as well as the dynamic interactions between cells in the consortia. One of the thoughts I have for this topic session is that how can we study the membrane protein functions to allow for effective transfer of metabolites between different cells inside a community or a consortia. For example, how can we use one membrane protein to secrete one metabolite from one cell and in the meantime use a variance of the same membrane protein to assimilate the metabolites into other cells to facilitate the cell to cell communication.
